reviewText: This is an artistic movie with more emphasis on theme than plot. The theme of the movie is hope. There are 3 seemingly unrelated plots.An American war veteran travels to Ho Chi Minh City to look for a daughter he fathered during the war.Kien An, a young woman, takes a job harvesting lotuses in the ponds of Teacher Dao, a reclusive man who has leprosy. Her singing awakens him from depression, and he asks her to write down poetry he has composed.The main story, is that about a cyclo driver, Hai, who stalks a prostitute after he had rescued her from a couple of thugs. He falls in love with her, wins a cyclo race, buys a night with her, treats her when she is ill and finally gets her back to school.The plots are very simple, predictable or even simplistic. There is only one truly happy ending - the story of the cyclo driver and the prostitute. The beauty lies in the way the scenes are shot. It makes one wonder if all this is dream or reality.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This film is really four stories in one. Two of them seem to carry greater weight: Kien An, a young woman with a beautiful voice, catches the ear of her employer, Teacher Dao, a poet afflicted with leprosy living in a home or sanatorium in the middle of a lake full of lotus blossoms, which his employees pick and sell in the public market. In a series of moving exchanges, she learns that he no longer writes because the disease has taken away his fingers. She offers to become his scribe; he accepts. Only later, as he nears death, do we learn the significance of the song she sang, which so captivated him.Hai, a cyclo driver with a heart and mind, falls in love with Lan, a beautiful prostitute who fears emotional involvement. As their relationship progresses we come to know them as complex human beings. Their final scene together is beautifully filmed in an unforgettable setting of falling red leaves.Woody, a street urchin, touches the heart as he moves through the rainy streets looking like a small ghost in his plastic rain poncho. Someone has stolen his case of contraband goods (US Marine lighters, watches, etc) and he has been told not to return until he gets it back. In the process he finds a new friend.Keitel plays an ex-marine who is looking for the daughter he fathered during the war. Although his role is much smaller than the advertising would lead you to believe, he turns in a fine, ultimately moving performance in which facial expressions tell the story far better than words. (This is true of the whole film, in fact.)In a larger sense, one might say that this film is about the search for meaning in an increasingly plastic and temporal society--represented by plastic, scented lotuses, Lan's heavy call-girl makeup, the bar scenes. I trust the authority of the Vietnamese reviewer who said it accurately portrays postwar Vietnamese society as well.The things I like about this film are: Cinematography, acting, understatement, humanity, and (ultimately) optimism for the future. I felt good when it was over.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I will not lie and say that Three Seasons is the most exciting movie in the world.  It is a slow film.  But it is a beautiful film and a look at Vietnam many of us have not seen.To me good Vietnam films were the war films like Platoon or Go Tell the Spartans.  But the war has been over since 1975 and I had no idea what was going on in Vietnam today until I saw this film.It is just a beautiful film of interconnecting stories in modern day Saigon.  I highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in seeing Vietnam past 1975 and in a way that is not a combat film.Again, it is a slow film, but one that is just so beautiful to look at.
summary: A Beautiful Look at Modern Saigon
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great movie, a great piece of story telling, and a great piece of filming, casting, and directing.  I saw it on the Sundance Channel and immediately came to Amazon to order the DVD.It's a beautiful film, telling a beautiful story, filmed in a superb manner.  The music and the poems add to the overall effetiveness.Note that it is a movie and was not meant to be a travel video.  It is a poetic, eloquent story and is not a documentary on 'modern Vietnam'.If you appreciate extremely well made movies, you will like this.Buy it new or used.
summary: One of the best movies ever
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you have ever visited Vietnam, the soundtrack alone will move you to tears. The three stories are simple but very moving. The contrast of old customs and ways and new modern expansion is so strong. The simple scene of the flower girl not able to sell her fresh flowers because of the new and improved plastic ones, tells volumes.The story of Harvey Keitel's character is the weakest and doesn't add much to the movie. But the other three stories make this movie worth seeing.
summary: Beautiful and moving contrast of old and new
Title: N/A

reviewText: The debut film of Tony Bui is a beautiful looking,poetic tapestry that is at once both intimate and epic. It intertwines three short stories, of very differet people living in present-day Vietnam, with a fourth involvng an  American ex-GI searching for the war child he's never met. The  sweet,tranquil film won the top three prizes at the Sundance Film  Festival,and is one of the best films of 1999.Harvey Keitel is great,as  always,as the vet. Highly recommended.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Vietnamese-American production follows a few different strands and tells various stories at once. One storyline follows a former soldier (Harvey Keitel) who returns to Vietnam for the first time since the war to find his daughter. Another storyline tells of a rickshaw driver who falls in love with a high class prostitute and eventually tries to take her out of the prostitution lifestyle. And yet another storyline tells of a young girl who works gathering lotuses and selling them on the street and who eventually becomes a scribe for a disfigured man whose head is full of poetry. It is a beautiful film and tears into emotional and societal issues.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A beautiful film that intwines the lives of many. Each of them  are in a different stage of life. You end up caring for all the charachters in this movie. Especially Hai,( the cyclo driver) who falls for a prostitute, and  Dao(the bitter, diseased old man) who hides himself from the world. As for  Keitel's prescence in the film, it's little more than a cameo. However,  Keitel works wonders in his limited role, giving a memorable performance.  There's no doubt that there are powerful forces at work here. This film is  more than worth your time. Director Tony Bui shows promise, and I look  forward to his future films.

reviewText: What a lovely film that touches the heart. It is truly an enchanting film with story lines that make you feel deeply in your soul. There were scenes that were so beautiful ... like the red flowers during summer time. The Vietnamese dress was breathtaking...in white floating within a forest of red.Take your time to welcome in a new culture and savor the beauty of its country. This movie is like a fresh air on a summer day. Highly recommended!!!

reviewText: THREE SEASONS is a lulling an even paced film about the three seasons of time in the life of Viet Nam and those involved in it's struggle:The time when there was purity;the time when purity was ruined;and the time that wholeness returns.This theme is played out in the daily lives of six people who are existing sometime (it is never clearly stated) in reconstructionist Viet Nam.Saigon plays host to Hai , a cyclo driver (a foot cabbie);Lan, a whore for whom Hai has a keen interest:Woody,a young street urchin who hawks his watches and lighters;Kien An,a seller of the floating lotus;the Master Teacher,who is a leper, whom Kien An becomes his scribe;and lastly James Hager,an American ex-soldier looking for his "half-caste" daughter.Each of these characters are broken souls because of the past turmoil in the country.Each has pain and struggles that needs to be dealt with and cleansed so that life can go on.The screenplay shifts it's focus continually from character to character developing the sense of what used to be,what is now,and what can be in this city where Western "progress" invades again.Make no mistake,THREE SEASONS has a totally Asian sensibility and must be viewed patiently and determinedly through that lens.The temptation will be to grow weary and impatient if you are expecting action.This film VERY quietly builds it's story and it's characters to a truly moving conclusion that will make the climax (subtle as it is) worth the exacting rising action.THREE SEASONS is a film that may not deliver the goods in the act of viewing it, but will pay off after the credits have faded.This is a very pensive and poignant piece of work.
summary: Post War Viet Nam: Returning to a time when there was purity and wholeness

reviewText: I just saw this movie in Istanbul film festival today and really loved it. Here is a film about love as well as the endless hope for achieving something which really means us in every perspective. Film's ending scene  is the most beautiful thing I have ever seen in movies for a long time.  Film really touches ones senses in every way. Short but meaningful  appearance by Keitel also adds to the flavour. Dont miss it If you havent  seen it already and take a walk in the emotional sea of white lotus  flowers.

reviewText: Tony Bui, the 26-year old writer and director of this film, escaped from Vietnam with his parents when he was two and was brought up in California. He received permission from the Vietnamese government to make this film, and it won awards at the 1999 Sundance festival for both best dramatic picture and cinematography.  It is the first film to be filmed in Vietnam in more than 30 years.The setting is Saigon today where modern commercialism is flourishing.  A visual feast of great beauty, I could feel the pull of Asia, and was drawn right into the interweaving stories of five separate individuals in four different stories, each story complete in itself.There's Kien An, a young woman hired to join a large group of women who gather lotus blossoms at sunrise and then sell them in the city.  Each glides in a separate small boat in the beautiful lotus pond and there is beauty and peace as they sing as they work.  Her song attracts the attention of her employer, a rich man who stays hidden because of his leprosy.  There's Woody, an extremely appealing little boy of about 6 who sells trinkets in the rain.  There's Harvey Keitel in a small part as an ex-American marine who returns to Vietnam to search for the daughter he fathered 30 years before.  And there's Hai, a cyclo driver who falls in love with a prostitute.  Cyclos are the cabs pedaled by drivers who wait in the shadow of the luxury hotels for tourists, earning small amounts of money for their hard labor. It is a difficult life, and the film depicted it well.  I could sense the strain in their muscles, see the sweat on their clothing, understand their anxieties and humble aspirations.Sometimes the stories were rambling.  Sometimes I didn't quite understand every single custom.  And sometimes I wished that everything would move faster.  But I realize the way the film was paced was part of the story. And I know there is much about Asia I don't  understand.  In spite of its faults, I recommend this movie.  It brings you right into an interesting and exotic world.  And introduces some characters who will linger long in your mind.
summary: A visual feast of interweaving stories in modern Vietnam

reviewText: I'd pay money to watch a Doritos commercial if i knew Harvey Keitel was going to be on it.  That was the reason i rented this movie.  It kills me, though, that film distributors in this country feel they need to stick a photo of a famous actor or actress on the cover so that the movie sells, and this is regardless of how minimal their role is.  Harvey Keitel is not the star of this movie, yet you would never know that by looking at the video box.  I fell for that same thing once with "Flirting", an Australian movie with Nicole Kidman all over the cover.  She actually had a very minimal part in the film, while the main characters are set in the background of the photo.But i digress: Three Seasons is a beautiful movie, vignette-style, where the paths of a few characters barely touch at times.  There are four basic stories.  The movie starts with the lotus blossom pickers, among whom there is this beautiful young woman who sings a touching poem while she works.  The owner of the lotus pond is a famous poet who has leprosy and lives hidden from the world.  After listening to the young woman, the poet summons her up and develops a beautiful and touching relationship with her.  Another story is the one of the rickshaw driver who falls in love with a prostitute, and shows her the true meaning of love.  Another story is the one starring Harvey Keitel.  He goes back to Vietnam searching for a daughter he has never met.  When he finally finds her, his heart is broken.  Finally, there is the story of two little panhandlers (and when i say little i really mean it: the boy was maybe 8, but the girl couldn't have been more than 5) and their troubles trying to survive in a harsh land.  The highlight of this movie is that it shows Vietnam as it is today, in all its raw beauty.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched this movie twice with my adopted Vietnamese daughter.  She was entranced with it, watching the scenes to see what she could recognize; and she did recognize much from her childhood.  All of the stories portrayed in  this movie are very accurate.  The only weak part of the movie was the  character that Harvey Keitel played.  Something wasn't developed enough  there...too many blanks and spaces.  I think the movie demonstrated that  we, as human beings, do what we have to do and not always whether we want  to or not.  Vietnam has suffered for many years with wars and poverty,  families being destroyed, and sadness beyond comprehension by most of us.  This movie shows all of that and more....but also gives us, the viewers,  hope that life really can go on, and flowers do bloom again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie based on the life of a Vietnamese poet named Han Mac Tu, but also based on the lives of the Vietnamese people after war (1975). In my thoughts, three seasons means three lives involved in the story: a poet retreated in a corner of life because of his illness; an American veteran searched his Asian-American daughter left at Saigon after the war; and a prostitute in present but always returns to her past as a schoolgirl beside her friends and her schools plenty of red flowers in summer. I like this movie by the story, by the scenes filmed at Saigon, and by the techniques of movie in modern time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is terrific. It is several stories of hope, love, redemption and beauty for people leading difficult, often desperate lives. The stories wind together through the interactions of the characters involved in the different subplots. Most of all it is stories of people finding each other and recognizing inner beauty when others may not. It displays the haunting beauty of Vietnam amidst the poverty that many people there live in daily. I was given a copy of this on VHS by a Vietnamese friend years ago. I was impressed by the music (singing of Kien An and the lady lotus pickers) and poetry (written by her employer, Teacher Dao, who is dying of leprosy and old age).  The sweet tenacity of the cyclo driver, Hai courting the prostitute, Lan. The search for and tender meeting of the marine (Harvey Kietel) with his daughter Phuong, from a wartime liaison with a bar girl. The struggle for subsistence of little Woody and the little street girl. I was so taken by it that I recently bought a DVD of it. It's a definite keeper. It is in Vietnamese with subtitles except where Harvey Kietel speaks. A very positive, heart-warming movie! You may need to keep a box of tissues handy if you are the emotional type. I get misty-eyed just thinking about it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Just about anyone who has seen this wonderful film is going to give it a minimum of four stars.  My only complaint--and it's not an insignificant one--is that the film was shot in widescreen, but the DVD is full screen.  It really needs a widescreen version, if for no other reason than that the cinematography of the Vietnamese landscape, which some of the reviewers have raved about, will allow you to see even more of Vietnam's beauty; plus, of course, "widescreen" is how the director intended for this film to be seen.UPDATE (1-14-2012):  I have a PAL widescreen (letterboxed) version of this film, which I noticed has "chopped off" about 20% of the top of the fullscreen version which I also have.  Consequently, I've come to conclude that the fullscreen (4:3) version actually shows more actual picture-content than the letterboxed version.  Apparently, some directors shoot their films in 35mm (fullscreen) and then crop the top and bottom for commercial widescreen theatrical distribution.  I would also note, however, that the letterboxed PAL version has better contrast, and sharpness, than my fullscreen version.  [The PAL (Region 2) disc can probably be ordered from amazon uk for ca. 15 or 16 bucks, including shipping].

reviewText: Tony Bui's latest work proves there is nothing immature about Vietnamese cinema. Together with "Cyclo," Bui's "Three Seasons"  provides insight into the Ho Chi Minh City underclass, but it departs from  Cyclo's sensationalism with a sensitive examination of human love. We visit  the relationship between a young girl from the provinces and an elderly,  dying poet; between two "bu doi," or street children, and that of  a returning GI and the daughter he never knew. On the heels of "Scent  of Green Papayas," Bui's latest work establishes him as a talent of  the first rank. This film is, in few words, an exercise in loving kindness  and beautifully done. Definitely worth purchasing and sure to be viewed  again and again.
Title: N/A
